newsitem.title: USA: U.S. mortgage-backeds gain, spreads widen slightly.
newsitem.headline: U.S. mortgage-backeds gain, spreads widen slightly.

text.p: U.S. mortgage-backeds gained as much as 1/2 point Thursday, but most spreads widened as the mortgage market underperformed U.S. Treasuries.

"People should have very neutral positions in mortgage holdings," said Cynthia Rivera, an associate director at BZW Securities Inc. Investors should avoid 8-9 1/2 percent coupons, where the risk outweighs rewards, she said.

Strong prepayments could be triggered in those coupons once 30-year Treasuries yield 6.50 percent. The yield fell 10 basis points to 6.62 percent Thursday on June's 5.0 percent unemployment and 0.3 percent average hourly earnings rise.

Treasury bond yields have to fall just 12 basis points for premium mortgage-backeds to "enter the danger zone" of prepayments, Rivera said. Mortgages would then lag Treasuries more sharply. Spreads would widen by as much as five basis points a day, compared with one to two basis points Thursday.
"The safest bet is in slight discounts or discount coupons" if the market advance persists, Rivera advised.

In key issues, Ginnie Mae 30-year 7.5 percent coupons were up 16/32 at 101-08/32 bid, yielding 98 basis points over 10-year Treasuries. Comparable Fannie Maes were up 14/32 at 101-04/32 and Freddie Macs were up 13/32 at 101-08/32.
